sentence: As the New Year unfolds, we make resolutions - to correct wrongs and make things right.
Applying this mantra to your portfolio would mean leaving behind those stocks that didn't treat you well in 2015 and investing in the ones that appear promising for 2016.
The year 2015 was indeed tough for many retailers, as persistent foreign currency headwinds and sluggish consumer behavior loomed.
In fact, leading players like fashion specialty retailer - Nordstrom Inc.JWN - also fell prey, plunging 30.5% in 2015.
Taking a look at this Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) company's earnings history, we note that it has underperformed the Zacks Consensus Estimate by an average of 6.4% over the last four quarters.

In fact, in the most recently reported third-quarter fiscal 2015 results, Nordstrom not only delivered a lower-than-expected bottom line, its top line also succumbed to a miss after delivering positive surprises for eight straight quarters.
The lower-than-expected results were mainly attributable to soft sales trends across all networks and merchandise categories, coupled with higher SG&A expenses and contracting margins.
Following a dismal quarter, management lowered its sales and earnings outlook for fiscal 2015, thus raising concerns.
Consequently, the stock witnessed downward estimate revisions, as analysts polled by Zacks turned less constructive on the stock's future performance.
Over the past 60 days, the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.39 and $3.58 per share for fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016 declined 10.6% and 12.3%, respectively.
With 2015 behind us, it's time to forget stocks like Nordstrom and gear up for a more gainful year.
Though 2016 began with markets in the red territory, the U.S. economy is largely healed.

Driven by factors like the slump in crude prices, increase in consumer spending, a gradual housing market recovery and improvement in the labor market, the retail space seems to be brimming with confidence.
In addition, the Fed's recent decision of hiking the interest rate by 25 basis points underscores the economy's underlying strength, which is another tailwind to the retail environment.
That said, it would be feasible on investors' part to add a few retail stocks with solid fundamentals to their portfolio.
Taking cue from these factors, we have zeroed in on four Retail-Wholesale stocks with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or #2 (Buy).
A favorable rank indicates positive estimate revisions by analysts who are optimistic on the future performance of the company.
One such stock which surely merits a spot in your portfolio is Abercrombie & Fitch Co.ANF .
Flaunting a Zacks Rank #1, the company outperformed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in three of the past four quarters, with an average positive earnings surprise of 87.1%.
Also, this Ohio-based retailer witnessed its earnings estimate for fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016 soar 36.4% to $1.05 per share and 12.7% to $1.15 per share, respectively, over the last 60 days.
Abercrombie remains focused on reviving its brands, enhancing performance and returning to profitable growth.
The company has long-term growth rate of 16%.
Another stock that is poised to carry the momentum into 2016 is American Eagle Outfitters Inc.AEO .
This specialty retailer of casual apparel, accessories and footwear registered positive earnings surprises in each of the past four quarters, with an average beat of 16.7%.
Further, this Zacks Rank #2 stock's earnings per share estimate for fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016 moved up by 2.9% to $1.08 and 1.8% to $1.15, respectively over the past 60 days.

Notably, this Pittsburgh, PA-based company remains committed to strengthening its product assortments by adding more compelling brands, managing inventory levels diligently and improving its eCommerce business.
Possessing a long-term growth rate of 10%, American Eagle surged 15.2% in 2015.
Investors can also count on Foot Locker, Inc.FL , which carries a Zacks Rank #2.
This New York-based retailer has been focused on exploitation of opportunities such as children's business, shop-in-shop expansion, store refurbishment and enhancement of assortments.
Backed by these efforts, the company registered positive earnings surprises in nine straight quarters, with an average surprise of 11.2% in the trailing four quarters.

Additionally, Foot Locker's earnings estimates have been trending upwards, as over the past 60 days, the company's estimates for fiscal 2015 climbed 1.2% to $4.26 per share, while it inched up 0.4% to $4.73 a share for fiscal 2016.
Clearly, a positive sentiment is palpable among analysts covering the stock with a long-term growth rate of 12.3%.
Last but not the least, it would be advisable to take advantage of home improvement retailer The Home Depot, Inc. 's HD bull run.
The stock, which surged 28.5% in 2015, looks promising with a Zacks Rank #2.
Home Depot is a leading player in the highly fragmented home improvement industry, which has been implementing several initiatives to drive long-term growth.
This Atlanta-based company outperformed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in seven straight quarters, by an average of 4% in the last four quarters.
Also, over the past 60 days, Home Depot witnessed earnings estimates for fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2016 move upward by 1.3% to $5.36 per share and 0.6% to $6.15 per share, respectively.
Finally, the company's long-term earnings growth rate of 14.2% further indicates its bright future.
Come 2016, it is time you forget Nordstrom and rejuvenate your portfolio with stocks like the ones mentioned above for guaranteed returns.
